title: Knowledge Integration for Disease Characterization: A Breast Cancer Example
segmentation: OK hi everyone, my name is O'shaughnessey Rodney and I'm from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute from Troy, NY and today I will be presenting our work on knowledge, integration for disease characterization as exemplified by breast cancer.
Some of you may know this month, October is breast Cancer Awareness Month.
So even if you are not in the health informatics field, you can probably learn something from this presentation.
At least that's my hope.
So this was submitted.

The resource track and the goals of this resource is to help a community medical oncologist who can clinically who can use clinically relevant information to come up with diagnosis, treatment options, and prognosis.

Because the information that they have to use rapidly changes because, as you might know, Cancer Research is evolving at a very rapid pace and they have to make clinical decisions based on information from multiple sources.
That may be only weeks or months old, and then the quality of the information should be easily assessed.
So this is the goal of our resource and the way we achieve.
This goal is this Bucklew, and as you can see there are multiple data sources.
One is authoritive data source called ACC American Joint Committee on Cancer staging.
And we also used in CIT.

That's National Cancer Institute, tesouras that has community accepted terms for cancer and we extracted some other data from here, which is surveillance Epidemiology and end results program and treatment.
An monitoring options from a resource called NCN National Comprehensive Cancer Network and we also used community sources like Civic.
Unk OK be for you know other treatment and monitoring options.
So I will go through some key steps.
In this work, so and then, the first step is how we built the ontology.
And one thing I want to.
The light here is that cancer staging is evolving.
So this here is a chart on the different editions of the cancer staging guideline in the US.
So the very first cancer staging guideline was published in 1977 and even in the inaugural cancer staging Guideline, the authors said that staging of cancer is not an exact science.
As new information becomes available, the classification and staging of the cancer will change.
So.
As you can see, like you know early this year.
8th edition came into effect, which makes the previous editions obsolete and this impacts many different groups of people.
Obviously impacts the patients because re staging can significantly change the treatment options for them.
For example, if they're downstage enough, they might not need chemotherapy.

Um Ann physicians, obviously, because they have to integrate these different data sources so you know, they have to do the recalculation when the guidelines change, and this might also impact researchers because they might want to understand the cancer biology of patients with population, population level, data insights.
So because this resource came into effect early this year, I think this resource is a very timely resource for the Community we are targeting.
So I know that.
Most of you are not in the health informatics field.
I'm also not technically in the health informatics field, so I had to do a lot of research.
A lot of reading to understand, so I'll give a high level overview of what we try to do with this.
So you probably have heard that cancers have stages, so if you take stage X it could be stage one, Stage 4.
Whatever stage in the previous edition it considered three different criteria.
The size of the tumor.
TN is the is whether the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes and M is whether the cancer has metastasized.
So going from age 67th to ACC 8th.
Those criteria still stay the same.
However, Additionally we have.
Is hormone level patterns or biomarkers, like estrogen, progesterone to grade and some.
You know criteria.
Also considered in determining the stage.
So with these new data streams.
Increases the complexity of figuring out the stage.
So just to give you.
Tampa, So this shot has, you know, let's say we have four different patients, different enm values and different biomarker values.
An according to the seven stage guide.
Blind this is a bad prognosis because the stage went from went up from 18228 now, so that means the patient has a bad outlook now.
However, you know these things are good.
For the patient, relatively good so you know it changes the prognosis of the patient or the treatment and monitoring options.
So what we did in.
Building this ontologies too.
We went through the manuals and we extracted the different combinations of these biomarkers and the TNM values.
So.
From the 7th edition we have only 19 and in the 8th edition they have a 407, so there's a huge increase in the complexity of these rules.
So just to give an example, in the GCC 7th edition for Stage One a, there's only one combination, but.
The 8th edition, that about 57 combinations.
So what we did was we.
Constructed all rules for these different criteria.
And so this is just a partial picture of the cancer staging ontology.
And here you have.

You know the 8th edition stage and we have multiple stages and for these different stages we have things like you know, recommended test, an treatment options and also sub stages for those superclasses.
OK, so.
The next step in the.
Process is to integrate or to build the integrated cancer knowledge graph.
For that we use.
This approach calls in.
Data dictionaries.
This is a pretty extensible way to integrate data from different data sources, and it uses this notion of semantic data dictionaries encode books.
I'll give you an example of this with you don't have to read it.
Standing of these things.
In fact, I graded out just so that you cannot read it.
So the only thing you have to realize is that like you know, this is the raw data you find in the wild, right?
Like you're not going to find Link data, or like you know you might then you're lucky, but in most cases you wouldn't find you know properly linked data.
However, you will find data like this in tabular formats.
So in order to make this data semantically meaningful, what we do is we take the column names and then we construct.
Semantic Semantic Data dictionary to how to put meaning to the data so.
Here, like you know we have these columns in the row data.
If we have to bring up a new concept to add some meaning, we can even create a virtual entry and then.
A domain expert can perform these semantic mappings.
Two existing concepts and we're using semantic science, integrated ontology, and some other you know ontologies for these mappings.
So that's the structure.
So what about that?
Pull data so in our data set we might have you know diseases, drugs, genes, an even indices as we might have things like no breast cancer.
We might have things like estrogen receptor, negative breast cancer, her two receptor negative breast cancer and there might already be community accepted terms for those particular cancers, right?
So we want to make sure that whatever the data that we generate a map to the correct terms.
So in the code book.
We actually find those terms and then we annotate those classes.
Yeah, so this column.
Has the raw data that is annotated and the value here or the code is sexual value in the cell and this is something that we find using tools like you know on to be.
So 1 interesting thing we found.
And this is just one set of data we have for tumor size T classes in the authoritative ages.
CDC guidelines.
It only has Steve.
So tumor size is equal to some class T1, but from other data sources like sea of example, they have many different data, so many different tumor classes like T1 in OSD One BT1A.
But by using this approach we can actually integrate all of these data sources and have a complete view of you know what other people use.
And these also support our integration in reasoning.
So which is another cool advantage?
OK, moving on.
The last part is, you know, we.
I said that one of the goals is to figure out the stage change from 7th edition to 8th edition.
In order to do that, we use reasoner to figure out the stage change.
For that we use.
So an agent, a deductive inference agent built on top of the wise Knowledge Graph framework?

So the patient data that's constructed using the semantic ETL process that I just described, the Semantic Data Dictionary process is loaded and then the guidelines that I initially described is also loaded as an ontology and then the stage staging status is in Ferd and we also have staging justifications with explanations at each.
Step of the chain.

So again, I apologize, this is not that readable, but given that patient data which includes demographic information and also there are biomarker TNN values, everything after doing the inference it will have an inferred knowledge.
So here for this particular patient the according to the seven stage in Group that person is 3 a according to the eight stage in Group that person is 1B, which means they have a better outlook.
Now I mentioned the end goal of this work is to help physicians, and we imagine physicians looking at these cousin rose diagrams.
Or, you know this.
You know, writing sparkle queries to look at, you know the inferred results.
No right?
So for that we actually create.
Ed.
Visualization again on top of device knowledge graph framework.
So I'll go through.
An example here we have an hypothetical patient D and so as you can see, the patients you know demographical information is loaded and there's also biomarker an other you know.
Test results loaded and this is something a physician would see I mean, this is like a report that the physician would normally see an in.
Here he can.
Seat so I have a call out here so the stage of this patient is 3 according to a pretty old guideline.
ACC 6th staging guideline and this stage type is detected through some kind of testing or you know based on the physician's intuition or whatever.
However, when we choose a GCC 8 staging criteria.
We can see that the stage actually drops to two B and you can see that the stage type is inferred.

And not only that, we also see the justifications for this for the stage change, as in like what changed from the previous change to the previous stage in the previous edition to the new stage in the new edition.
And then we because we integrate knowledge from different sources.
We have things like, you know, biomarkers that might impact some drugs or monitoring options that they can take.
So.

In the earlier stage, I think it was 3A and the patient was prescribed a bone scan, but in the new treatment options, that bone scan is not there, so just imagine it will actually cost, you know, healthcare costs, at least in the US for the patient.
So this is the tool that we developed for the physicians and we actually wanted to see that.
You know, this is a real problem, like, you know, is the stage does change a lot from previous edition to a new addition.
So we.

Found an evaluation with 250 patient records from CIA in that like you can see this is a flow diagram where you know the left hand side has the 7th edition and the right hand side has the 8th edition so you can see you know in majority of the cases the stage actually doesn't change, but you know there are many edge cases where the stage does change and that's important because cancer is increasingly becoming personalized and you know with the inclusion of genetic information.
In a pre next staging guideline you might be able to see like you even more you know changes between stages.
So in.
For this particular track, we these are the resource contributions we have these ontologies they're available on bioportal, and we're also making the semantic annotations available.
We have made all our source code open source.
We have the guideline extractor that can pass the agency staging manuals and then you know a tool that can generate the axioms and also the custom inference rules for the wise knowledge graph.
And also the visualization and we also have made the data available as well.
With that, I conclude my presentation.
I encourage you to go and take a look at.

Website and also we have two posters and demos this afternoon so one is for this, you know ontology enable breast cancer characterization work and we have another post and demo on the wise Knowledge Graph framework.
So please come and take a look and we can do a deeper dive on both of those systems and this work is ongoing and we are extending this work to other kinds of cancers to diabetes.
So more we should talk.
And if you are interested in collaborating with us, please contact myself and Deborah McGuinness sitting at the front and also we are hiring RPI is a great place to work.
We have positions from software engineer to reset stuff to tenure track faculty.
So please do apply with that.
I'll take any questions that you might have.
